title: 113_hr1582
content: The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013" prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules costing over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. Prior reports and determinations are required before finalizing such rules. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with a copy of the rule, a concise statement about it, total cost estimates, and total benefits estimates. The EPA must report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. The report must include a copy of the rule, total cost estimates, total benefits estimates, and certification of data accuracy. The EPA must report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. The report must include total cost and benefits estimates, along with a certification of data accuracy and availability for public review on the Agency's website. The EPA must report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. The report must include total cost and benefits estimates, certification of data accuracy, and availability for public review on the Agency's website. Additionally, it should contain an estimate of energy price increases and a detailed description of employment effects resulting from the rule. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will conduct an independent analysis to determine the potential impacts of the rule, including effects on electricity prices for consumers and employment, such as job losses and shifts in employment. The Secretary of Energy, with input from relevant agencies, will conduct an independent analysis to assess the rule's impact on energy prices for consumers, fuel diversity in electricity generation, and energy supply. The Secretary of Energy will conduct an independent analysis to assess the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity in electricity generation, and energy supply, including any adverse effects on energy distribution or use. The Secretary of Energy will determine if the rule will cause adverse effects on energy distribution or use, consulting with other relevant agencies. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with other relevant agencies, will determine if the rule will have significant adverse effects on the economy, considering costs, benefits, and impacts. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with other relevant agencies, will determine the economic impacts of the rule, including costs, benefits, and effects on economic indicators. The results will be published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "direct costs" and "indirect costs" are defined as per the Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines. The term "energy-related rule that is estimated to cost more than $1 billion" refers to EPA rules regulating energy production, supply, distribution, or use, estimated by the Administrator. The term "rule" in this Act refers to any regulation related to energy production, supply, distribution, or use that is estimated to impose direct and indirect costs exceeding $1 billion. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to the cost described in a technical support document. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to the cost described in a technical support document published by the Interagency Working Group on Social Cost of Carbon in May 2013. The House of Representatives passed a bill related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions on August 1, 2013. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
